greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Product_{primes p dividing n } gcd(p-1, n-1).
comment: a(n) = number of bases b modulo n for which b^{n-1} == 1 (mod n).
A049559(n) divides a(n) divides A000010(n). - _Thomas Ordowski_, Dec 14 2013
Note that a(n) = phi(n) iff n = 1 or n is prime or n is Carmichael number A002997. - _Thomas Ordowski_, Dec 17 2013
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (terms 1..1000 from T. D. Noe)
W. R. Alford, A. Granville and C. Pomerance, There are infinitely many Carmichael numbers, Ann. of Math. (2) 139 (1994), no. 3, 703-722.
R. Baillie and S. S. Wagstaff, Lucas pseudoprimes, Mathematics of Computation, 35 (1980), 1391-1417.
P. Erdős and C. Pomerance, On the number of false witnesses for a composite number, Mathematics of Computation, 46 (1986), 259-279.
Romeo Meštrović, Generalizations of Carmichael numbers I, arXiv:1305.1867v1 [math.NT], May 04 2013.
formula: a(p^m) = p-1 and a(2p^m) = 1 for prime p and integer m > 0. - _Thomas Ordowski_, Dec 15 2013
mathematica: f[n_] := Times @@ GCD[n - 1, First /@ FactorInteger@ n - 1]; f[1] = 1; Array[f, 92] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Aug 08 2011 *)
program: (PARI) for (n=1, 1000, f=factor(n)~; a=1; for (i=1, length(f), a*=gcd(f[1, i] - 1, n - 1)); write("b063994.txt", n, " ", a) ) \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Sep 05 2009
return len([1 for witness in range(1,n) if pow(witness, n - 1, n) == 1])
a063994 n = product $ map (gcd (n - 1) . subtract 1) $ a027748_row n
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 18 2001
ext: More terms from _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 21 2001
